subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone
msgSnippet: Hi Grant, I believe that Quickscript is better than Shavian. I believe Read improved Shavian and that improvement is Quickscript. I think that Shavian has
messageBody:
Hi Grant,
 
I believe that Quickscript is better than Shavian. I believe Read improved Shavian and that improvement is Quickscript. I think that Shavian has received and does receive more press and therefore is more popular.
 
I believe you might be guessing right that the NBC speak is not the best to further the use of Quickscript. One of the possible advantages of Quickscript is that it is not an American development. Nonetheless, the NBC speak is perhaps the best dialect because it is the most widely used. Anyway, there is a lot to do before worrying about which dialect is the best for Quickscript or how to best fit Quickscript to various dialects or vice versa.
 
 -----Original Message-----
From: grantlsinclair [mailto:grantlsinclair@...]
Sent: Wednesday, August 28, 2002 4:49 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone

Hi everybody.

I know I'm new to the group and first heard of Shavian and Read only a
few days ago, but I'm so full of shit that I thought I'd give an
opinion on standardised spelling.

Outisde of the U.S, the Anglo-speaking world is in the grips of fear
and denial when it comes to american culture taking over the world.
Any attempt to standardise spelling based on the NBC dialect will be
met with extreme resistance (come to think of it, why don't you have a
compulsory .COM.US domain?). Would that mean I'd have to give up
putting my U in colour? I guess I have to anyway.

My solution to the problem of squabbling between Americans, English
and Australians over who speaks 'proper' english is to let it be done
by either New Zealanders, the Scottish or the english speaking Indian
population. Sure we wouldn't have any comprehension of the
pronounciation but at least nobody feels threatened by the global
takeover of Scottish culture.

Okay, then. How about Canada? They sound pretty damn similar to
americans but nobody seems to hate them (except Quebecians). Their
version of english is about as phonetically, culturally and
diplomatically neutral as they come.

--end of bullshit

Since I only encountered Shavian/Read recently, I never really looked
at the Shavian community. I just heard that Read had improved his
original and so I just skipped straight to Quikscript. But from
discussions here it would seem that the Shavian community is
considerably bigger. Does anyone know why? Is it just that it's older? 

Could someone please point out any positive points to Shavian - why it
might be better than quikscript. I'm just a little confused as to why
the outdated one would be more popular.


I was also wondering if there were any Lojbanists here? [Lojban being
a constructed language with an emphasis on logic and unrhymability]


sincerely,

grant sinclair

no, I'm not canadian. I'm australian

Hi Grant,

I believe that Quickscript is better than Shavian. I believe Read improved
Shavian and that improvement is Quickscript. I think that Shavian has
received and does receive more press and therefore is more popular.

I believe you might be guessing right that the NBC speak is not the best to
further the use of Quickscript. One of the possible advantages of
Quickscript is that it is not an American development. Nonetheless, the NBC
speak is perhaps the best dialect because it is the most widely used.
Anyway, there is a lot to do before worrying about which dialect is the best
for Quickscript or how to best fit Quickscript to various dialects or vice
versa.

 -----Original Message-----

Sent: Wednesday, August 28, 2002 4:49 PM

Subject: [Read_Alphabet] NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone


  Hi everybody.

  I know I'm new to the group and first heard of Shavian and Read only a
  few days ago, but I'm so full of shit that I thought I'd give an
  opinion on standardised spelling.

  Outisde of the U.S, the Anglo-speaking world is in the grips of fear
  and denial when it comes to american culture taking over the world.
  Any attempt to standardise spelling based on the NBC dialect will be
  met with extreme resistance (come to think of it, why don't you have a
  compulsory .COM.US domain?). Would that mean I'd have to give up
  putting my U in colour? I guess I have to anyway.

  My solution to the problem of squabbling between Americans, English
  and Australians over who speaks 'proper' english is to let it be done
  by either New Zealanders, the Scottish or the english speaking Indian
  population. Sure we wouldn't have any comprehension of the
  pronounciation but at least nobody feels threatened by the global
  takeover of Scottish culture.

  Okay, then. How about Canada? They sound pretty damn similar to
  americans but nobody seems to hate them (except Quebecians). Their
  version of english is about as phonetically, culturally and
  diplomatically neutral as they come.

  --end of bullshit

  Since I only encountered Shavian/Read recently, I never really looked
  at the Shavian community. I just heard that Read had improved his
  original and so I just skipped straight to Quikscript. But from
  discussions here it would seem that the Shavian community is
  considerably bigger. Does anyone know why? Is it just that it's older?

  Could someone please point out any positive points to Shavian - why it
  might be better than quikscript. I'm just a little confused as to why
  the outdated one would be more popular.


  I was also wondering if there were any Lojbanists here? [Lojban being
  a constructed language with an emphasis on logic and unrhymability]


  sincerely,

  grant sinclair

  no, I'm not canadian. I'm australian
